title: The New Heavens and Earth
shortSummary: Isaiah 66 reveals God's sovereign majesty and judgment, contrasting false worship with true humility and reverence. It prophesies the future restoration of Jerusalem, the gathering of nations, and the eternal new heavens and earth where God's glory will be fully revealed.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - Late 8th century BC, during the prophetic ministry of Isaiah

keyCharacters.name: The LORD
keyCharacters.description: God speaking throughout the chapter, declaring His sovereignty, judgment, and future promises.

keyCharacters.name: Zion/Jerusalem
keyCharacters.description: Personified as a woman who gives birth and a city of rejoicing, representing God's people and the center of His future glory.

keyCharacters.name: The Nations
keyCharacters.description: Gentile peoples who will be gathered to witness God's glory and bring offerings to Jerusalem.

definitions.definition: A humble and repentant heart that recognizes sin and turns to God for mercy.
An offering or sacrifice presented to God, often referring to grain or animal sacrifices.
The future eternal state of creation renewed and perfected by God, free from sin and suffering.
A reverent fear and awe of God's commands, leading to obedience and humility.

outline.heading: God's Sovereignty and True Worship
outline.description: God declares His transcendence over creation and rejects empty, hypocritical sacrifices, emphasizing that He looks to the humble and contrite who fear His word.

outline.heading: The Birth and Joy of Zion
outline.description: The chapter portrays Zion giving birth miraculously and calls God's people to rejoice in Jerusalem, promising comfort and peace like a flowing river.

outline.heading: God's Judgment on the Wicked
outline.description: God will come in fiery judgment against those who practice abominations and false sanctification, demonstrating His holiness and justice.

outline.heading: The Gathering of Nations and the Glory of God
outline.description: God promises to gather all nations to witness His glory and send messengers to proclaim it, bringing offerings and priests from among the Gentiles.

outline.heading: The Eternal New Creation and Worship
outline.description: God promises the permanence of the new heavens and earth and the continual worship of all flesh, concluding with the eternal punishment of the wicked.

application: Approach God with a humble and contrite heart, valuing reverence over ritualistic worship.
Rejoice in God's promises of comfort and restoration, trusting in His faithfulness to His people.
Live in holy obedience, aware that God will judge sin and abominations with righteous fury.
Share the gospel boldly, knowing God will gather all nations to Himself and glorify His name.

keyVerses.text: But to this man will I look, even to him that is poor and of a contrite spirit, and trembleth at my word.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's preference for humility and reverence over empty sacrifices, teaching the heart attitude He desires.

keyVerses.text: As one whom his mother comforteth, so will I comfort you; and ye shall be comforted in Jerusalem.
keyVerses.significance: God promises tender and personal comfort to His people, assuring them of His loving care.

keyVerses.text: And it shall come to pass, that from one new moon to another, and from one sabbath to another, shall all flesh come to worship before me, saith the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse points to the eternal worship of God by all peoples in the new creation, emphasizing the centrality of worship in God's kingdom.

keyVerses.text: And they shall go forth, and look upon the carcases of the men that have transgressed against me: for their worm shall not die, neither shall their fire be quenched; and they shall be an abhorring unto all flesh.
keyVerses.significance: A sobering reminder of the eternal judgment awaiting the unrepentant, underscoring the seriousness of sin.
